data.title: Fox CEO confirms plans for DTC streaming service by end of 2025
data.description:
Fox (NASDAQ:FOX) CEO Lachlan Murdoch on Tuesday confirmed plans to launch a direct-to-consumer streaming service by the end of calendar year 2025.

The announcement comes months after the three-way joint venture between Fox, Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD), and Disney (DIS) for sports streaming fell apart.

During the earnings call, he clarified that the service would not incur incremental rights costs and would be priced modestly.

The subscription streaming service is expected to include content from Fox News and Fox Sports.

Murdoch did not elaborate further about the service or its pricing strategy. He said expectations for subscriber numbers "would be modest."

The service by Fox comes at a time when live sports and event streaming are on the rise.

Lachlan Murdoch on Fox's Q2 earnings call said, "We see the traditional cable bundle as, still, the most value for our customers and frankly the most value for the company. So we are huge supporters of the traditional cable bundle and will always be. But that said, we do want to reach consumers wherever they are, and there is now a large population outside the traditional cable bundle, either cord-cutters or cord-nevers. And we are designing… an offering to really target those cord-cutters and cord-nevers that are not traditionally in the cable bundle.

“We do not want, and we have no intention of turning a traditional distribution customer into a DTC customer. So our subscriber expectations will be modest, and we are going to price the service accordingly.”

“With these modest expectations, we do not expect any exclusive rights costs or additional incremental rights costs. This service will be a package of our existing content and existing brands targeted to consumers who are not currently in the bundle. So the incremental cost will be relatively low, certainly relative to what our peers… are spending in the space.”

data.title: Tempur Sealy to close Mattress Firm acquisition on Wednesday
data.description:
• Tempur Sealy (NYSE:TPX) plans to close its acquisition of Mattress Firm on Wednesday after a federal judge on Friday denied the Federal Trade Commission's request to block the $4 billion deal.
  • Tempur Sealy (NYSE:TPX) will hold a conference call on Thursday to discuss the transaction, according to a statement on Tuesday.
  • On Friday, a federal judge denied the FTC's efforts to block the merger, rejecting the FTC’s claims that Tempur Sealy (TPX) planned to limit competitors access to Mattress Firm and lose access to the single most important retail channel.

data.title: BP pauses $1B Australia biofuels project in latest cost-cutting move
data.description:
BP (NYSE:BP) said Tuesday it is pushing back plans to make renewable fuels at the site of its former Kwinana oil refinery in Australia, the latest step in the company's broader cost-cutting drive.

BP (NYSE:BP) had planned to build a biofuels project that would produce sustainable fuels from biomass and a green hydrogen plant dubbed H2Kwinana.

"While bioenergy remains a core part of BP's strategy, BP has decided to re-phase the Kwinana renewable fuels project," the company said, and the revised plan will allow it to improve capital efficiency and better align the project with government policies.

BP's (BP) decision was said to include the increasing cost of construction and the lack of a mandate in Australia to use the fuels, leaving the company unsure whether there would be a viable local market, according to UpstreamOnline.com.

The cost of the Kwinana Renewable Fuels project has been reported at A$580M, while a public conceptual study estimated the first stage of H2Kwinana to cost A$399M.

The Kwinana refinery, which was once Australia's largest oil refiner with a capacity of 146K bbl/day, was converted into a fuel import terminal in 2021 due to low refining margins and regional oversupply.

The KRF was set to become the first of five BP (BP) plants worldwide to turn biomass, including used cooking oil, into 10K bbl/day of sustainable aviation fuel and renewable diesel.

data.title: Roche's Susvimo gets FDA approval for diabetic macular edema
data.description:
Roche's (OTCQX:RHHBY) Genentech unit has received FDA approval for its drug Susvimo 100 mg/mL injection for the treatment of diabetic macular edema, a leading cause of blindness for people with diabetes.

Susvimo, also known as ranibizumab injection, was first approved by the FDA for the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration in 2021.

data.title: TransDigm projects $8.85B fiscal 2025 revenue with steady aftermarket growth
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: TransDigm Group Incorporated (NYSE:TDG) Q1 2025

Management View

  • Kevin Stein, President & CEO, highlighted a strong start to fiscal 2025, driven by robust growth in commercial aftermarket and defense revenues. Commercial OEM revenues were down slightly, impacted by supply chain disruptions and a machinist strike at Boeing. He emphasized the company's focus on shareholder value creation through proprietary aerospace products and aftermarket revenues.

  • Stein noted that TransDigm deployed $300 million for share repurchases in Q1, buying approximately 250,000 shares at an average price of $1,249 per share, aligning with long-term return objectives.

  • CFO Sarah Wynne stated, "Free cash flow was over $800 million for the quarter," attributing it to strong operational performance and timing of interest and tax payments. She confirmed fiscal 2025 free cash flow guidance remains at $2.3 billion.

  • Joel Reiss, Co-COO, reported sequential and year-over-year bookings growth across all market channels, with commercial aftermarket revenue increasing 9% compared to the prior year.

Outlook

  • The company reaffirmed fiscal 2025 guidance, projecting $8.85 billion in revenue, reflecting 11% growth. EBITDA is expected to reach $4.685 billion, up 12%, with a margin of 52.9%.

  • Market channel growth assumptions include mid-single-digit growth in commercial OEM, high single-digit to low double-digit growth in commercial aftermarket, and high single-digit growth in defense.

  • Adjusted EPS guidance was raised slightly to $36.47, reflecting share repurchases.

  • Management reiterated that uncertainty around Boeing's production ramp-up remains a risk factor but maintained guidance given the current market fundamentals.

Financial Results

  • The company reported strong EBITDA margin performance at 52.9% in Q1, supported by a favorable commercial aftermarket mix and productivity initiatives.

  • Free cash flow exceeded $800 million due to operational efficiencies and timing of payments. Cash on hand was approximately $2.5 billion at the end of the quarter.

  • Commercial aftermarket revenues grew 9% year-over-year, supported by strong passenger air traffic and increased demand for engine-related products. Defense revenues also rose by 11%.

  • Commercial OEM revenues declined by 4% year-over-year due to the Boeing machinist strike and supply chain delays.

Q&A

  • Myles Walton, Wolf Research, asked about sequential EBITDA margin improvements. Sarah Wynne explained it was driven by a mix shift toward higher-margin commercial aftermarket and productivity initiatives. She noted the mix effect was significant in Q1.

  • Noah Poponak, Goldman Sachs, questioned the flat margin guidance for the remainder of the year. Kevin Stein stated it reflects conservatism and the impact of acquisitions, which average down margins by approximately 1%.

  • Robert Stallard, Vertical Research, inquired about submarket growth within the aftermarket. Stein pointed to freight as a lagging submarket but noted signs of stabilization.

  • Jason Gursky, Citi, asked about refurbishment activity. Joel Reiss stated that interiors remain below 2019 levels due to constrained airline fleet planning, but noted that refurbishment would pick up as OEM deliveries improve.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed slight skepticism regarding OEM production recovery and margin stability, particularly in relation to Boeing’s performance.

  • Management maintained a slightly positive tone, emphasizing operational resilience and confidence in achieving guidance. Kevin Stein remarked that "we remain focused on our value drivers" and highlighted improvements in supply chain dynamics.

  • Compared to prior commentary, management appeared more cautious about OEM recovery timelines but remained firm on guidance.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • No previous quarter transcript was available for comparison.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management highlighted ongoing challenges with Boeing’s machinist strike and its lingering supply chain effects, which could delay OEM production recovery.

  • Analysts raised concerns about inventory unwinds and their impact on OEM revenues. Management acknowledged limited visibility into OEM inventory levels but indicated preparedness for fluctuations.

  • Interiors in the aftermarket remain below pre-pandemic levels, with refurbishment activity delayed by constrained fleet availability.

Final Takeaway

TransDigm Group started fiscal 2025 on a strong note, driven by robust growth in commercial aftermarket and defense revenues. Management reaffirmed full-year guidance of $8.85 billion in revenue and $4.685 billion in EBITDA while raising adjusted EPS expectations to $36.47. Despite uncertainties surrounding OEM production and refurbishment activity, the company remains confident in achieving its targets, supported by strong cash flow generation and a focus on capital allocation through share buybacks and M&A opportunities.

data.title: Sen. Hagerty said to propose stablecoin bill for clear regulatory framework
data.description:
Senator Bill Hagerty (R-TN) is reportedly set to unveil a bill Tuesday that would create comprehensive regulatory guidelines for stablecoins, aligning with the GOP's push to foster a crypto-friendly environment under President Donald Trump.

Stablecoins like tether (USDT-USD) USDC (USDC-USD) and are a type of cryptocurrency designed to keep a steady value by being pegged to the U.S. dollar (or another stable asset).

“My legislation establishes a safe and pro-growth regulatory framework that will unleash innovation and advance the President’s mission to make America the world capital of crypto,” Hagerty said in a statement, Bloomberg reported.

The proposed Guiding and Establishing National Innovation for US Stablecoins — or GENIUS Act — lays out regulations for the issuance of stablecoin payments to back stablecoin payments with assets such as Federal Reserve notes and Treasury bills, Bloomberg explained, citing a draft bill.

If approved, the legislation will require stablecoin issuers to disclose monthly audited reports regarding their reserve mix. The quality of reveres that back stablecoins have drawn increased regulatory scrutiny in recent years, amid concerns about the liquidity of certain reserves in the event of market pressures.

data.title: ADM outlines $2B portfolio simplification opportunities amid cost management push
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Archer-Daniels-Midland Company (NYSE:ADM) Q4 2024

Management View

  • Juan Luciano, Chair of the Board and CEO, highlighted that ADM reported Q4 adjusted EPS of $1.14 and full-year adjusted EPS of $4.74, aligning with the midpoint of guidance. Total segment operating profit for Q4 reached $1.1B, with full-year operating profit at $4.2B.
  • Luciano emphasized operational improvements, such as record crush volumes in LATAM and enhanced performance in Starches & Sweeteners, which achieved 3% higher production year-over-year. Two flavors acquisitions were successfully integrated, contributing to the EMEA region's performance.
  • ADM announced targeted cost reductions of $500M to $750M over the next three to five years, including $200M to $300M planned for 2025. This involves reducing 600 to 700 roles, realigning efforts, and identifying structural savings.
  • The company disclosed $2B in portfolio simplification opportunities, including potential divestitures and closures of underperforming assets or those with excess capacity.
  • CFO Monish Patolawala noted that while Q4 played out as expected, December faced pressure from unfavorable crush margins and higher manufacturing costs. The AS&O segment operating profit declined by 32% year-over-year.

Outlook

  • Management expects a challenging first-half of 2025, with significantly lower soybean and canola crush margins. Soybean crush margins are projected between $45 to $55 per ton, down $5 per ton year-over-year, while canola crush margins are expected to range from $50 to $70 per ton, down $20 per ton.
  • Patolawala stated that operational improvements and cost savings are expected to mitigate some market headwinds. For the full year, AS&O segment performance is anticipated to be "below to similar" to 2024 levels.
  • Nutrition segment operating profits are forecasted to improve in 2025, driven by stronger performance in Flavors and Animal Nutrition, alongside cost optimization. However, Q1 2025 is expected to remain under pressure due to ongoing challenges at the Decatur East facility.
  • Adjusted EPS for 2025 is projected between $4.00 and $4.75, reflecting lower margins but offset by $200M to $300M in cost savings.

Financial Results

  • Q4 adjusted EPS was $1.14, slightly below analysts' estimates of $1.15. Revenues for the quarter were not explicitly mentioned in the transcript.
  • The AS&O segment reported a Q4 operating profit of $644M, down 32% year-over-year, driven by weaker crush margins and higher costs. Full-year operating profit for the segment fell 40% compared to 2023.
  • Carbohydrate Solutions' Q4 operating profit was flat year-over-year, supported by robust demand for ethanol and strong North American starches and sweeteners margins, partially offset by weaker EMEA results.
  • Nutrition achieved Q4 operating profit of $88M, supported by improved mix and insurance recoveries. However, organic revenues in the segment declined due to demand challenges and higher manufacturing costs.

Q&A

  • Tom Palmer, Citi: Questioned the expected recovery in nutrition profits in 2025. CEO Luciano explained that improvements would stem from the Decatur East facility resuming operations, strong growth in Flavors and Biotics, and margin improvements in Animal Nutrition.
  • Andrew Strelzik, BMO: Asked about vegetable oil demand post-45Z guidance. Luciano noted expectations of a 5% increase in soybean oil's share of feedstock while emphasizing policy clarity's importance for stabilizing margins.
  • Ben Theurer, Barclays: Sought clarification on the AS&O segment’s expected Q1 decline. CFO Patolawala cited lower crush margins and reduced insurance proceeds but highlighted operational efficiencies expected to improve results later in the year.
  • Heather Jones, Heather Jones Research: Inquired about potential cost recoveries in 2025. Patolawala estimated insurance proceeds would range between $50M to $100M in 2025 from the Decatur East incident.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed concerns over weak Q1 projections and the impact of policy uncertainties, highlighting skepticism about margin recoveries and operational headwinds.
  • Management maintained a cautiously optimistic tone, emphasizing internal cost controls, portfolio simplification, and operational improvements as key levers for navigating a challenging environment.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management displayed consistent confidence in addressing operational inefficiencies, while analysts remained focused on unresolved headwinds and policy-related risks.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for adjusted EPS was narrowed to $4.00-$4.75 for 2025, reflecting a more conservative outlook compared to the $4.50-$5.00 guidance from Q3 2024.
  • Management’s focus shifted towards identifying $2B in portfolio opportunities, a new strategic initiative not emphasized in the prior quarter.
  • The tone during Q4 was slightly more defensive, with management highlighting uncertainties in biofuel policies and trade environments compared to the broader optimism expressed in Q3.

Risks and Concerns

  • Trade policy uncertainties with China and Canada could impact crush margins and export volumes.
  • Regulatory ambiguities surrounding biofuel policies, including the 45Z guidance, add volatility to soybean oil demand.
  • Ongoing operational challenges at the Decatur East facility continue to weigh on the Nutrition segment.
  • Lower insurance recoveries in 2025 and cost pressures from inflation and manufacturing inefficiencies pose additional risks.

Final Takeaway

ADM is navigating a challenging operating environment with a focus on cost management, operational improvements, and strategic portfolio simplification. While near-term headwinds, including weaker margins and policy uncertainties, weigh on the outlook, management’s emphasis on $2B in portfolio opportunities and targeted cost savings of up to $750M positions the company for long-term shareholder value creation.

data.title: Cabot projects $7.40-$7.80 EPS for FY2025 amid growth in performance chemicals
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Cabot Corporation (NYSE:CBT) Q1 2025

Management View

  • CEO Sean Keohane emphasized strong execution despite a mixed economic environment, reporting adjusted EPS of $1.76 for Q1 2025, a 13% increase year-over-year. EBIT in Reinforcement Materials grew 1%, while Performance Chemicals saw a 32% rise due to higher volumes and demand stabilization.
  • The company generated $124 million in operating cash flow, with $77 million invested in growth projects, including new capacity in Indonesia for Reinforcement Materials and battery materials in China. $66 million was returned to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.
  • CFO Erica McLaughlin highlighted a strong liquidity position of $1.3 billion and a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.3x. Capital expenditures for FY2025 are expected to be in the range of $250 million to $300 million.
  • Keohane reaffirmed Cabot’s long-term growth strategy centered on the "Creating for Tomorrow" pillars of grow, innovate, and optimize, targeting an adjusted EPS CAGR of 7%-10% over the next three years.

Outlook

  • Management reaffirmed FY2025 adjusted EPS guidance of $7.40 to $7.80, supported by stable Reinforcement Materials EBIT and growth in Performance Chemicals. Performance Chemicals is expected to maintain quarterly EBIT in the $45 million to $55 million range.
  • Demand for infrastructure-related products, especially in wind energy and power distribution cables, is projected to drive growth, while auto-related sales are expected to align with flat global tire production levels.
  • The company anticipates a gradual ramp-up of its Indonesia Reinforcement Materials capacity in the latter half of FY2025, with significant contributions expected in FY2026.
  • Tariffs on US-Mexico-China trade are being assessed. The direct impact is expected to be minimal, but downstream effects on demand remain under evaluation.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted EPS for Q1 2025 was $1.76, up from $1.56 in Q1 2024, driven by EBIT growth in both business segments.
  • Reinforcement Materials reported EBIT of $130 million, benefiting from higher volumes and favorable pricing but offset by a less favorable geographic mix and lower energy center revenue. Performance Chemicals’ EBIT improved by $11 million year-over-year, supported by an 8% volume increase.
  • Total operating cash flow was $124 million, with discretionary free cash flow at $114 million. Shareholder returns included $24 million in dividends and $42 million in share repurchases.
  • The operating tax rate for Q1 2025 was 28%, with the full-year tax rate expected to range between 27%-29%.

Q&A

  • Chris Perrella, UBS: Asked about Reinforcement Materials contract terms and volumes. CEO Keohane explained base prices remained flat year-over-year, with volume increases in Europe offset by challenges in the Americas due to Asian tire imports. He noted modest EBIT gains in H2 2025 from Indonesia capacity.
  • John Roberts, Mizuho: Inquired about the impact of rising oil prices on specialty blacks. Keohane indicated adjustments in spot pricing to maintain margins while emphasizing the company’s track record of margin management.
  • Lydia Huang, J.P. Morgan: Queried drivers of Performance Chemicals’ 8% volume growth. CFO McLaughlin attributed growth primarily to fumed metal oxide products, which saw a 20% increase, and carbons and compounds, which grew by 5%-6%.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed cautious optimism, focusing on global demand shifts, margin management, and tariff impacts. Concerns centered on competitive pressures in the Americas and the outlook for tire production.
  • Management maintained a confident tone during prepared remarks, emphasizing strategic execution and growth opportunities. However, during Q&A, responses were more defensive, addressing challenges in Reinforcement Materials and trade dynamics.
  • Compared to Q4 2024, both management and analysts displayed consistent confidence in long-term strategies, with analysts slightly more pressing on near-term risks.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Reinforcement Materials EBIT remained stable, but the Q1 2025 outlook included modest sequential improvement from seasonally higher volumes in Europe, contrasting with Q4 2024’s lower volumes.
  • Performance Chemicals continued its recovery, with EBIT growth driven by demand stabilization and higher-margin applications. Q1 2025 results were stronger than Q4 2024, which had higher maintenance costs.
  • Management's tone reflected continued confidence in strategic execution. Analysts maintained focus on competitive dynamics and cost pressures, similar to prior discussions.

Risks and Concerns

  • Challenges include the impact of Asian tire imports on North American volumes, potential downstream effects from new tariffs, and competitive pressures in Reinforcement Materials.
  • Management emphasized operational excellence and geographic diversification as mitigation strategies. The company also expects minimal direct impacts from tariffs due to existing agreements allowing cost pass-throughs.

Final Takeaway

Cabot Corporation delivered strong Q1 2025 results, with a 13% adjusted EPS growth and significant EBIT gains in Performance Chemicals. The company reaffirmed its FY2025 EPS guidance of $7.40 to $7.80, supported by infrastructure-driven demand and operational efficiencies. While competitive pressures and trade dynamics pose challenges, Cabot remains confident in its long-term strategy, underpinned by disciplined capital allocation and targeted capacity expansions in Indonesia and battery materials.

data.title: Atkore signals $375M-$425M adjusted EBITDA for FY 2025 amid pricing challenges and growth initiatives
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Atkore Inc. (NYSE:ATKR) Q1 2025

Management View

  • CEO Bill Waltz highlighted that Q1 performance met expectations with net sales of $662 million and adjusted EBITDA of $99 million. Adjusted EPS reached $1.63, near the top end of their guidance range. Organic volume declined 5% due to tough year-over-year comparisons.
  • Waltz noted the company remains on track with growth initiatives related to water and global construction services, with planned contributions later in the year to support PVC and HDPE water products. He emphasized a focus on mitigating pricing pressures and advancing strategic initiatives to expand into new markets.
  • Management reduced their full-year adjusted EBITDA outlook to a midpoint of $400 million, down from previous estimates, citing larger-than-anticipated impacts from competitive pricing pressures in PVC and steel conduit markets.
  • CFO John Deitzer provided additional insights, stating that average selling prices decreased by 12% in Q1, primarily driven by PVC and steel conduit products, and outlined steps to manage costs and improve operational efficiency.

Outlook

  • Management provided Q2 guidance with net sales expected between $685 million and $715 million, adjusted EBITDA of $85 million to $95 million, and adjusted EPS of $1.30 to $1.50. For FY 2025, full-year adjusted EBITDA is projected in the range of $375 million to $425 million, with adjusted EPS between $5.75 and $6.85.
  • Waltz mentioned that the company expects a stronger performance in the second half of FY 2025 due to seasonal construction activity and ramping up of growth initiatives. The guidance assumes no material benefit from tariffs on imported conduit but acknowledges potential upside if tariffs are enacted.

Financial Results

  • Q1 net sales reached $662 million, with adjusted EBITDA of $99 million and a tax rate of 21%, up from 17.5% in the prior year. Organic volumes declined 5%, and average selling prices fell by 12%, driven primarily by PVC and steel conduit pricing pressures.
  • Metal framing, cable management, and construction services grew mid-single digits, supported by global mega projects. In contrast, plastic pipe and conduit volumes declined mid-single digits, reflecting increased import competition and tough prior-year comparisons.
  • Management highlighted improvements in operational performance at facilities such as Hobart, Indiana, which supported sequential margin gains within the S&I segment.

Q&A

  • Andy Kaplowitz, Citigroup, questioned the impact of PVC import competition and sought clarity on the dynamics affecting metal conduit volumes. Bill Waltz explained that PVC imports grew over 20% year-over-year and emphasized that the pricing pressures are factored into the revised guidance, which assumes market normalization to pre-COVID levels by year-end.
  • Deane Dray, RBC, inquired about the drivers of the guidance cut and the contribution of PVC versus steel. CFO Deitzer clarified that approximately 75% of the pricing impact comes from PVC, with the remainder from steel conduit. Waltz added that additional domestic PVC capacity and imports have further pressured prices.
  • Chris Moore, CJS Securities, asked about the fiscal 2025 bottoming outlook. Waltz highlighted ongoing productivity improvements, growth in water-related products, and contributions from global mega projects as key drivers for recovery.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts displayed a slightly negative tone, focusing on pricing pressures and the competitive landscape, particularly in PVC and steel conduit markets. Concerns centered around the company's ability to navigate these headwinds and deliver on revised guidance.
  • Management adopted a cautiously optimistic tone, emphasizing operational improvements and growth initiatives. Waltz expressed confidence in the company's ability to manage challenges, stating, "We remain committed to executing our strategy to deliver value for shareholders."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, sentiment has shifted slightly more negative, reflecting increased competitive pressures and lowered guidance.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance was revised downward, with FY 2025 adjusted EBITDA projections reduced to a midpoint of $400 million from $500 million previously forecasted. This reflects a more cautious outlook on pricing dynamics in PVC and steel conduit markets.
  • Analysts' focus shifted from general growth opportunities to concerns about competitive pressures and pricing sustainability.
  • Management's tone was slightly less confident compared to Q4 2024, with a greater emphasis on mitigating risks and cost management.
  • Growth initiatives such as water-related products and global mega projects remained key strategic priorities, consistent with earlier quarters.

Risks and Concerns

  • Competitive pricing pressures in PVC and steel conduit markets were highlighted as significant challenges. Waltz cited increased imports and new domestic capacity as key factors.
  • Analysts raised concerns about the ability of the company to stabilize pricing and sustain profitability amid these headwinds.
  • Management outlined mitigation strategies, including cost structure optimization, productivity improvements, and advancing growth initiatives in water and construction services.

Final Takeaway

Atkore's Q1 2025 results met expectations, but competitive pressures in PVC and steel conduit markets prompted a downward revision to full-year guidance. Management remains focused on advancing growth initiatives in water-related products and global mega projects while navigating pricing headwinds. Analysts raised concerns about the ability to sustain profitability, but management highlighted productivity improvements and strategic investments as key drivers for recovery in the second half of the fiscal year and beyond.

data.title: Disney's profit in focus during Q1 earnings
data.description:
Walt Disney’s (NYSE:DIS) profitability will be in focus, when the entertainment giant reports first quarter results on Wednesday, before markets open.

Wall Street expects the California-based company to post EPS of $1.43, indicating a 17% increase from last year, while revenue is expected to rise nearly 5% to $24.55 billion.

Disney’s robust earnings projection, combined with growth in its flagship streaming video service and the success from Box Office hits including Moana 2 and Mufasa: The Lion King, comes at a time when the Mouse House is preparing to name a new chief in early 2026, replacing veteran Bob Iger.

The company, in November, forecast profit growth in FY2025 to reach high single digits and to increase to double-digit growth in earnings per share in fiscal 2026 and 2027, even as it is planning to make investments in theme parks and cruise ships. On the buyback front, Disney also set a target of $3 billion for the fiscal year.

Even though, analysts are positive on Disney’s Entertainment unit, many are focusing on the company’s Experiences segment, given the impact from hurricanes Helene and Milton and cruise ship pre-opening costs. The company also faced a slowdown in attendance after a post-covid surge.

BofA analyst Jessica Reif Ehrlich said he projects Q1 to be “the trough quarter of this fiscal year,” adding that it does not appear the recent Los Angeles fires have had a material impact on Disneyland attendance until now.

“We project a mid-single digit decline in F1Q25 (-5%) weighed down by Hurricane impacts and pre-opening costs for the Disney Treasure, improving to +4% in F2Q and full year growth of 7%,” noted Guggenheim analyst Michael Morris, while talking about the Experiences segment.

Disney Treasure is a cruise ship that began its maiden voyage in December last year. Disney cruises are part of the company’s experiences division, alongside theme parks, resorts and consumer products.

Over the last two years, Disney has beaten EPS estimates 88% of the time and has beaten revenue estimates 50% of the time.

Wall Street and Seeking Alpha analysts are bullish and recommended the company as a Buy, while Seeking Alpha’s Quant Ratings rated it as a Hold.

Over the last three months, EPS estimates have seen 13 upward revisions compared to three downward revisions. Revenue estimates have been revised upward six times versus seven downward moves.

The company’s stock has gained 18% in the last one year, compared to the over 20% rise in the broader S&P500 Index.
